subject: chemistry
title: Atomic Structure
description: Understand the structure of atoms — protons, neutrons, and electrons — with interactive 3D atomic models.

labSteps.title: The Nucleus
labSteps.instruction: The nucleus is at the center of the atom and contains protons (positive charge) and neutrons (no charge). Scale up to see it clearly.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Understand that the nucleus contains protons and neutrons.

labSteps.title: Protons
labSteps.instruction: Protons have a positive charge and determine the element's atomic number. Tap a proton to highlight it.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Identify that atomic number = number of protons.

labSteps.title: Electrons
labSteps.instruction: Electrons have a negative charge and orbit the nucleus in energy shells. Rotate to see the electron cloud.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Understand electron shells and why atoms are electrically neutral.

labSteps.title: Isotopes
labSteps.instruction: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons. Drag to add/remove neutrons from the nucleus.
labSteps.expectedOutcome: Define isotopes and understand that neutron number can vary.

questions.question: Where are electrons located in an atom?
questions.explanation: Electrons orbit the nucleus in specific energy levels called electron shells or orbitals.

questions.question: What determines an element's atomic number?
questions.explanation: The atomic number is the number of protons in the nucleus. Each element has a unique atomic number.

questions.question: What are isotopes?
options: Atoms with different numbers of protons
Atoms with different numbers of neutrons
Atoms with different numbers of electrons
Different elements with the same mass
questions.correctAnswer: Atoms with different numbers of neutrons
questions.explanation: Isotopes are atoms of the same element (same number of protons) but with different numbers of neutrons.

questions.question: What is the charge of a neutron?
questions.explanation: Neutrons have no electrical charge. This is why adding or removing neutrons creates isotopes without changing the element's identity.
